page.title: 20The Village of Salwarpe
page.content: The village of Salwarpe is mentioned in the original{Domesday Book.}The name is derived from "seal" meaning salt and "weorpen" meaning to tow a boat. The village consists of 23 {houses,}many of which are over 100 years old, a modern{rectory,}and a {Village Hall,}built by the villagers in the early 1970's. The Hall is used by many organisations, including the W.I.,Dog Training,Youth Club,etc. The {Droitwich Barge Canal,}built by James Brindley in 1771, runs through the village. After many years of disuse, it has been dredged and restored recently and is now navigable from Droitwich to Ladywood. Close by the canal is{Salwarpe Court,}a 16th Century half-timbered manor house of great historical interest. The original owner of the Court was Catherine of Aragon.
